description:
Throughout the eons, hordes of aliens and beasts from across the galaxy have descended upon the planet of Fantos in search of Iridium, the life force of all existence. As the hordes multiplied, conflict became commonplace, splintering the population into rival citadels. Eventually, war, greed, and the depletion of resources pushed Fantos to the brink of destruction, and in response to the planet's cry for help, Zodraz, the Cosmic Warden, intervened, sentencing the planet to a great cull to be survived by only a single worthy citadel.

Fate of Fantos: The Iridium Wars is a tableau-building card game with competitive and co-operative elements for 3-6 players, each assuming the role of a unique citadel of Fantos. Each are responsible for hiring acolytes to manage their affairs, with the ultimate goal of obtaining the most Iridium, and therefore the most favorable position when Zodraz finally arrives.

Citadels must manage their Iridium harvesting strategically, however, as it further contributes to the pollution of Fantos, revealing new trials along the way. Zodraz also unleashes plagues, summons cosmic creatures, and forces dissent between the citadels as the game progresses. Citadels must choose whether to resolve them together as a planet, or watch as rival citadels struggle to survive.

Ordinary roll-and-move game along a 100-space track, with event spaces such as "lose a turn" and "move forward X spaces". There is one space involving player choice, as a risky shortcut can optionally be attempted. The illustrations and descriptions chronicle events in a normal day for Blondie and Dagwood in a largely non-chronological fashion.

There's no publication date, but the logo used is from the 40s or 50s.

—user summary

Harakiri: Blades of Honor is a multi-campaign cooperative board game of adventures and fantasy for up to 4 players. After a bloody civil war, the Emperor was banished and the empire fell into the darkness, governed under the tyranny of the Dark Shogun.
Pick one hero, each of them with their background and skill tree, to embark with your gaming group on an epic adventure. Travel through Japan, where you will be able to trade, visit shrines to increase your divine connection with your associated god, learn about the story of each character and many more, in an evolving map which will react to your decisions failures or successes.
Each hero shall have a customized board with many options to decide your way of playing. Will you focus on divine powers, unleashing a devastating God Mode to use as a final option sacrificing your own body on the process? Or would you prefer to unveil your own history via personal missions? Many options are laid before you and choices will have to be made along the way.
The game will include many travel events where your hero could go into the magical forest of the Tengus, travel to cursed villages and battle with the help of his blade the terrifying creatures of Japanese mythology… Some of these event cards can be turned into even more dangerous events depending on your hero decisions. Will you travel following safer roads to avoid potential conflicts or will you choose to go through more dangerous sideways to gain some precious time needed to achieve your goals before the Dark Shogun keeps on spreading his influence and power all over the land?
Besides this, the combat system will also allow you to choose your way of playing. You will be able to decide if you want to use heavier and more damaging blows or faster ones, giving you extra time for other purposes. Also, you will be able to choose if you want to focus during your attack, allowing you to go through the enemies’ defense or diminish it for the rest of the battle. But beware, because a failed attack could even lead to a terrible counter from one of the many japan folklore-based members of the Shogun Horde. Not only that, but also during each and every attack the energy of the kami could give even more power if you are lucky enough to get the right combination from the yin-yang symbol dices. Finally, the dice-based skill system will also allow for powerful moves during your turn, giving passive or active effect to choose from. But beware, cause the more powerful a skill is, the harder it will be to use it again, adding a tactical layer to the game. 
Besides all the mechanics, we think that a good story is a crucial part of immersion and fun, and for that we are honored to have one of the top fantasy Spanish writers, David Velasco, in our team. Get ready to dive into a branching and evolving story, where decisions can deeply affect the outcome of upcoming sessions.
Regarding art production we count on well-known artists and illustrators who have made fantastic pieces of art to recreate the Japanese culture. Our sculptors have created incredible minis to get a deeper immersion in the extensive world of Harakiri.
Hone your blade and fight for your clan like a hero and get involved in the wonderful lands of Harakiri!

SYNERGIC GAMES

—description from the publisher

Fairies love parties.
However, they never host it themselves. It's a hassle for them to send out invitations and arrange a hall for it. This is where you come in!
You set up the party for them and in return receive "Sparkles".
But be careful! Don't start the party until all the fairies have gathered. If you try to start the party prematurely, you'll put the fairies in a bad mood!

Gameplay:

The player is helping fairies and in return receiving Sparkles. The player will play fairies (cards from value 0-3) to party halls face down. If you think you've gathered 5 or more fairies, give the order and start the party.
If a player has gathered 15 or more chips (sparkles), the game ends. At that point, the player with the most chips is the winner.

—user summary

Devil May Cry: The Bloody Palace is an easy to learn, fast-paced, and dynamic experience where style counts for everything. Take control of one of Devil May Cry’s iconic demon hunters, Dante, Nero, Trish, or even the newest addition to the series, the mysterious V.

Players will be trying to outscore each other by building the most impressive attack combos. Utilising the cards in their hand to build the biggest combo chain; the longer the chain the more Style Points you'll score.

Will you keep pushing your combo or will you claim it early? A bigger combo scores more points, but a single hit from the demons surrounding you can break the chain!

The winner is the devil hunter who can score the most Style Points after a set number of enemy waves; featuring hordes of Empusa, behemoth Antenora, and towering bosses!

—description from the designer

The Enneagame™ is a card game based on the 9 fundamental personality types of the Enneagram. Wield the unique abilities of each type to avoid Identity Crisis cards and be the last player standing!

You avert the identity crisis by playing a self-discovery card from your hand. Some of the self-discovery cards have special abilities as well, related to the specific personality types, and others are just general self-discovery cards.

Play as each personality type.

—description from the designer

Summary:

The king has organized a royal ball, at the end of which the princess is going to finally choose a husband. Players begin with 4 cards each, playing 1 card on the table each round. The cards in the deck represent different guests attending the ball, each with their own unique ability. Use these to peek at, trade, or steal cards from other players. The two players holding the "Princess" and "Prince Edward" cards during the final round are declared the winners.

This game can be played by anywhere from 4 to 8 people, but some cards are used only if you have enough players. This means bigger groups will result in new abilities, forcing players to change up their strategy.


Gameplay:

1. Deal 4 cards to each player.
2. The player holding the "Princess" card must flip her over so everyone can see.
3. All players choose 1 card from their hand and place it face down on the table.
4. The player holding the "Princess" flips over their chosen card and carries out its ability.
5. Continue clockwise around the table, each player activating their card's ability.
6. Once all players are finished, the round ends.
7. Repeat steps 3-6 two more times.
8. When all players have 1 card remaining, everyone places their cards face-up on the table. The 2 players holding the "Princess" and "Prince Edward" cards during the final round are declared the winners.

Will you aim for the "Princess" knowing everyone at the table can see exactly where she is? She is sure to draw the attention of other players, moving back and forth just like she would in a dance hall.

Or will you instead try your luck and search for "Prince Edward" instead? Some guests will give players the ability to pinpoint where he is hiding!


Various card effects:
Baron: All players take a random card from the hand of the player to their right.
Wizard: Trade your entire hand with another player.
Foreign Royal: Choose a card from your hand and trade it for the Princess.
Priest: You are exempt from all actions that affect a player's hand until your next turn.


—description by Raw Potions Publishing, publisher of the English localization

Best of the Super Slime is a trick-taking game for 3 to 5 players.  Each player can play any card to a trick; there is no obligation to follow suit.  The highest card played in a non-lead suit will win the trick, with the tie going to the later card.  The winner collects all cards played to the trick.

The cards won go towards increasing the size of that player's "slime".  However, at the end of a hand, players will score points for the size of their slime (sum of the collected ranks) in relation to 100.  Points earned can be 0, 1, 2, 4 or 6.  For instance, if the sum of the player's cards won is larger than 100, the slime has collapsed and a player only receives 1 point.  If multiple players have a size less than 100, then the smallest of these is declared the Worst of the Small Slime and earns 0 points.

The game lasts 3 hands and the player with the highest cumulative points wins.

—user summary

ä¸­ã®äººãªã‚“ã‹ã„ãªã„ï¼ (Nobody, inside!) is a mix of trick-taking and blind auction bidding, for 3-6 players. The deck shows visitors to a theme park, with the low cards also doubling as the costumed characters trying to get the visitors to ride on the attractions.

The game is played in alternating rounds of trick-taking and blind auctions. During the trick-taking, players follow normal trick-taking rules (follow the lead if possible, play a trump otherwise).

The winner of the round then leads a blind bidding, placing costumed cards face-down plus chips. Players that don't want to or cannot play a costumed mascot play a visitor instead, face-up as a discard. The winner of the auction collects visitors fom the other players, and sets the next trump colour.

At the end of the game, the players get points for the visitors they have earned, and a bonus for colour majorities.

The deck consists of cards 1-15 in 4 colors. Ranks 1-8 are "Visitor" cards, and ranks 9-15 may either be a "Visitor" card of rank 9-15 or rotated 180 degrees to be a "Costumed" card of rank 1-3. The game also comes with bidding chips which are distributed to the players.

The lead player has the option of starting a "Visitor" trick or a "Costumed" bid. A "Visitor" trick proceeds as a standard trick-taking game with players each playing a card from their hand (following suit if possible), and the winner being the player that played the highest ranked trump card, and if none were played, the highest ranked card in the lead suit.

In a "Costumed" bid, any player, including the lead player, that plays a "Costumed" card, plays it face down. Such players can also add up to 3 of their bidding chips to their card. Any player who does not want to or cannot play a "Costumed" card instead plays a "Visitor" card face up. At the end of the trick, the highest combined value of chips and "Costumed" card takes the trick, with the latter played breaking ties. The trump suit for "Visitor" rounds is determined by the last "Costumed" card color to win a "Costumed" trick.

The winner of the "Costumed" trick chooses between scoring all "Visitor" cards played to the trick that match the color of the winning costume or acquiring cards of this color from in front of the other players.

Players play a predetermined number of rounds, with the rules suggesting 3. Points are earned based upon the visitors scored during "Costumed" tricks and the number of colors of visitors obtained during "Visitor" tricks.

—user summary

Queens and Kings ...A Checkers Game is an abstract strategy game for 2 or 4 players that plays like checkers and in addition introduces a queen component that throws strategy out the door on each and every move. The game can be played in either two player  or team mode. 
More about the game: The Queen, being tired of a male dominated game that either features only the King or the Queen in a lesser role, created a 2/4-player game that  shows the Queen’s ability to be the master of the game . 
Queen and Kings ...A Checkers Game, introduces a Queen scepter in the center of the board, upon capturing it the King is introduced. The King can move one space in any direction, forward or backwards along its diagonal grid. Advancing your piece to the opposite end of the board creates a Queen that can fly diagonally across the board, seizing all opponents in her path. Both Queen and King have a strategic value, so choose wisely because once a Queen or King that  piece remains so until defeated or game is over. Each game starts with either 9  pieces that can only move forward along its diagonal grid, so be mindful of the Queen and her pursuit of her opponents 
In Queens & Kings ...A Checkers Game, In Team mode it takes a coordinated effort to defeat your opponents. The 9 piece- games plays out in about 30 minutes to 90 minutes. 
What will be your strategy? The Queen now sits next to the King on her throne and peace and harmony reigns in the kingdom, or does it?

Based on the award-worthy investigative journalism program (IJP), Whatever Happened to Pizza at McDonald's? (The Board Game)  simulates the battle between the Friends of Truth (those who would seek to uncover the true reason why McDonald's stopped serving pizza) and the Enemies of Truth (those who would keep this foul secret at all costs).

2-4 players will command their factions in a fierce competition that includes tactical movement around the dual-ringed board, risky management of resources, and clever card play using both "Tricks of the Trade" and "Undercover Ops".

Whatever Happened to Pizza at McDonald's? (The Board Game) combines the simple strategy of classic games with the diabolical intrigue of journalistic potboilers such as "All the President's Men".

In Bidders!, a.k.a. ãƒ“ãƒƒãƒ€ãƒ¼ã‚º, the players are the leaders of craftsmen guilds and try to balance profits and support of the people.

The King has money, and bidding on his projects can be profitable, but your popular support will fall. The Prince is well supported, but has a limited budget.

At the end of the game, the player with the lowest support is ineligible to win, and the player with the most money of the remaining players will win.

—user summary

Board game designed for 2-5 players aged from 12 years.

Rat race in the Corporation - it's not a catch. To climb the top of the KORPO S.A. in Mordor, get as many prestige points as possible. To this end, players collect First, Second, Third and Top Degree Attribute Cards. The one who scores the most points wins.

Players traverse a board (a corporate skyscraper) using action cards and visit various rooms and offices which enable them to collect attribute cards (representing various objects). Specific sets of these cards can be exchanged for a stronger attribute card of a highers level which usually give winning points and sometimes additional bonuses.

—description from the publisher

It’s been 10 years since the Animaccord team started the production of the Marsha and the Bear cartoon. The series, which today, without any overstatement, has been a worldwide YouTube phenomenon that has conquered the hearts of billions of kids and their parents throughout the world.
This special board game is created and issued to mark the 10th anniversary of Animaccord Studio’s establishment.  Step by step, you will pass through all stages of production of an animated series – starting with script writing all the way to the first episode releasing on air.  Will you be able to sell the brand’s licensing for the creation of consumer products?  Are you ready to be at the top of your industry and get international success?
The game vividly shows all the obstacles that the Animaccord studio has handled over the last 10 years.  Just like in real life, you will face the design, technical, and financial issues, as well as the legal specifics of business management – simply everything behind the scenes of the tremendously popular cartoon.
Feels like a challenge?  Of course!  But, we believe that you will accomplish this mission and find success with your beloved heroes.  Marsha and the Bear despite all obstacles you will face on your path.  The Animaccord team has done it, so can you!
We wish you good luck!

—description from the back of the box

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Sovereign is a game similar to Risk, Settlers of Catan, and Monopoly, if all were rolled into one game.

Players will manage their TEMPER Attributes in order to remain in power. TEMPER stands for Trustworthiness, Economics, Military, Population, Environment, and Resources. Each of these Attributes are needed to maintain a healthy nation and a healthy ruler.

Players will spend 1/2 of each Round in a specific phase, played at the same time. Event Phases are set up as follows:

     Players draw event cards.
     Players solve event cards in one minute.
     Players vote on other player's solutions.


The second phase is the Action Phase, where players expand by buying tiles or trading for them, build Resource collectors, or make armies. There's a lot you can do during this phase.

Players will play until either all are eliminated or one Sovereign remains.

—description from the designer

Which magician is the first to collect enough magic symbols? As if by magic, some paths in the magical labyrinth are closed. Only those who know the right spell, i.e. the secret colour, may move on.

In this travel-version colour-coded tabs replace the magnets of the full version, which leads to a more memory like experience.
This version has a 4x4 board, where the full version has a 6x6 board.

—user summary

The game contents 24 coloured pieces (12 of each colour) and 6 uncoloured pieces (parallelepipeds “1 x 2 x 3”) and 4 borders to make the frame for the game.
Each player takes the pieces of one colour and 3 uncoloured pieces.
The aim of the Game is to connect the longest series of pieces of your colour. 
Uncoloured pieces count as either colour.
The players take turns to place one of their pieces in the frame. It can be placed flat, on its side or vertically. 
Each piece placed must be against another piece and / or an edge and must not be placed against a piece of the same height.
The game ends when one of the players can't play any more.
The players count their longest series of pieces, including uncoloured ones. They must deduct one point for any unplayed uncoloured pieces.
The winner is the one with the highest score.

—description from the designer

In Nine Tiles Panic (ãƒŠã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ« ãƒ‘ãƒ‹ãƒƒã‚¯), each player has a set of nine double-sided town tiles.

At the start of a round, three scoring cards are revealed, such as most aliens on a single road, most dogs visible, or longest road. All player then race to assemble their town in whatever pattern seems best, trying to score points for one, two, or three of the scoring cards as they wish. As soon as the first player decides that they're done, they flip the sand timer and everyone else has 90 seconds to complete their town, then players determine who scores for which cards, with ties being broken in favor of whoever finished first. Players score points based on the number of players in the game, and players track their score on a chart over multiple rounds.

This is a family game to test your memory. Can you find the secret code hidden in the castle?

In da Vinci Castle, you play the game on the assumption that Leonardo da Vinci has built six castles. He has a  hidden a different secret code  in each castle, and if you decrypt it, you can destroy it. Maybe it's a genius' eccentricity to hide these deadly weaknesses in the castle that he built.

Each player receives a piece with a color and a piece with a number, creating a castle with a secret password. And when it's your turn, you either ask questions or attack.

You can ask questions only to the player on your left. Choose a color and a number and say, "Do you have red or four?" If the player who was asked has either, they say yes, if they have neither, then the player goes on to say no. Ask questions to get a clue to what the other player's secret password is.

Once you are sure what the other player's secret password is, you can attack your opponent and destroy their castle. However, if you attack your opponent's castle with the wrong secret code, you must be careful because your castle will collapse and you will be eliminated from the game.

—description from the publisher

Temple of War is a heavy wargame using an innovative combat and skirmish system. The game will come with several full-fledged campaigns and can be played from 1 to 10 players (or more). The campaign is built in such a way that the players can play different stages at the same table or individually at home, and update the state of the game/world based on their progress. It's possible to drop out or jump into any game at any time, as each player controls their own army/faction. The game can adapt to any situation on the fly, without the need to restart or wait for each other. The game will come with an app, so you will be able to engage in a campaign with anyone around the world.

The theme of the game is based on a never before used (in boardgames) high-fantasy IP that will be revealed later next year.

—description from the designer

Four master spies seek to gather information for their respective governments and return to their headquarters. This is a pure roll-and-move game. Player order is determined by an initial die roll, and all movement is determined by die rolls. The track is 65 spaces long and includes obstacles like "Lose 1 Turn" and "Roll 2 to Leave." If, during the game, a player lands on an occupied space, that player must return all the way to the start space.

Some spaces on the board require players to draw a "Confidential Card." These include such directions as "Return to the Warehouse. Confirm report that premises are now being used by a Foreign Government, as a base for operations. (Lose two turns.)" and "Conditions now favorable in your sector. Roll die two times. Add up the total and move ahead."

The winner is the first player to reach the finish space.

—user summary

Longboat is a strategic drafting game in which for 2 - 4 players compete to build the most glorious Viking longboat.

Players take it in turns to draft cards from a central pool called The River and add them to their boat. Scoring or 'Glory' is based on a number of factors, including the loyalty of the vikings on board and the amount of Loot the player has amassed.

Special cards activate abilities, such as Berserkers that allow a player to steal loot from another's boat. Or sheep that are used to weigh down opponents and rob them of glory.

—description from the designer

Story
The game Iron Forest takes place in a fantastical land called Neemus. Several different clans call Neemus home, including Wolf Clan, Hedgehog Clan, Rabbit Clan, and the Owl Clan. While the many clans have called this land home for as long as they can remember, they know they were not the first to live here. On the edge of Neemus lies a place the clans call Iron Forest, filled with strange looking structures and creations. Upon deeper exploration, the combined forces of Animal Clans discovered incredible technology that they quickly learned how to use, creating their own amazing machines that helped them develop their own civilization. However, one day, Iron Forest sprang to life and rose into the sky, building machines of their own. This Iron Force has one objective: to take back the technology stolen from Iron Forest. Now Animal Clans must fight back to protect their homeland.

Gameplay
Iron Forest is a flicking game for 2-4 players, split into two opposing teams: Animal Clans or Iron Force. Each scenario offers asymmetrical objectives that each side needs to fulfil in order to win. Scenarios involve players trying to control certain areas of the game board, destroy opposing team mechas, collect certain objects, and much more. On their turns, players draw cards from their team's activation deck, then activate the mecha depicted on that card by either flicking it or launching it. Players also have access to a range of different power-up cards that will grant their side unique abilities, turning the tide in their favour!


—description from the publisher

A nearby solar system has been obliterated by a supernova. Now is your time to move in and extract the valuable resources from its unstable planets — but these jobs are too dangerous to do alone, so send in teams of Hired Paws and form uneasy truces with your rivals to come away with the best loot.

Afternova is a strategic negotiation game for 3-6 players. Score victory points by collecting fragments shown on your blueprints to build ship upgrades. When a player completes 6 of blueprints, the game ends and the player with the most victory points wins.

On your turn, you may either take 3 cards from the market or extract fragments from a planet. When performing a Market action, you can take any combination of Blueprint and Hired Paw cards. Blueprints are needed to score points, but they also grant special abilities. Hired Paws have different skill sets, so you'll need a variety of Hired Paws to Extract, or help other players Extract. The core of the game is negotiating during an Extract action. When performing an Extract action, you often don't have all the Hired Paws needed to meet the planet's requirement, so you'll likely need to team up with other players to split the work and the rewards.

—description from the designer

The royal family is preparing to go to bed, but no one can decide what they want to wear! Each member of the family keeps getting out of bed to put on new pajamas, then goes back to bed — but not necessarily to sleep.
 But as soon as the ghost appears, everyone hides under the quilt. Who can remember in which bed the King is located? Or who is wearing blue?

Each turn in Le Roi Sommeil, players draw a card from the deck, then place the character in bed. If this is the first time the character is going to sleep, you place it in an empty bed at the front of the line; otherwise, you replace the character already in bed with the newly dressed character.

When someone draws the ghost, they immediately cover all the beds with the quilt to hide all the characters. Each player then draws a token that shows either a character or a color, and they need to find a bed in which this person or color is located.

Want to be a mighty BattleClaw warrior? Play the exciting Battle Mode and Advanced Battle Mode game at home — or anywhere you want!

You and one other player can face off for an epic match of BattleClaw in both Battle Mode and Advanced Battle Mode! Take turns using your claw to catch Jinlins and create powerful beasts to attack your opponent. The first player to defeat all 3 of the opponent’s beasts wins the game!

—description from the publisher

Hyper Battle Kaiju Fight Snow & Ice Battlepacks include 4 randomly selected Kaiju Battlecards (2 of which are new random 'Snow & Ice-themed kaiju) , 3 random Zone cards (1 of which is a new random Snow & Ice Zone) , 2 Bonus Cards and rules!

This is a standalone pack and can also be integrated with any other Hyper Battle Kaiju Fight Battlecards.

Based on the original kaiju characters of game designer and manga artist Alex Strang, Hyper Battle Kaiju Fight is an action-packed (yet simple to play) monster-fighting game using large ‘Battlecards’.

Each player uses a Battlecard to represent their giant monster. The large-size illustrated card has all of the monster's abilities and strategic moves arranged on the back, using a unique tactical grid system for battling and tracking results.

Kaiju Battles can end in many ways, from total defeat (monster explode!), concession, running away, draws, and more.

Also: Circular Zone Cards represent various planets and other galactic environments that affect gameplay, and Bonus Cards provide surprising extra moves and events that can alter battles.

The game can be played with 2 players, and becomes even wild with multiple players.

-description from designer

With Escape Room in a Box: Flashback, you and your friends can play the ultimate room escape game at home -- and the heat is on! Your team of 2 to 9 players has 90 minutes to find clues, solve puzzles and crack codes in order to escape the mad scientist werewolf, Doc Gnaw. Solve 22 puzzles and unlock 4 real combination locks to construct a powerful amulet that holds the key to your freedom! This unique, three-path escape room game can be played UP TO THREE TIMES -- if you stick to one path during gameplay, you can play again on a different path with no overlap. And there's help from the outside: players can connect with Amazon Alexa to enhance the gameplay of Escape Room in a Box: Flashback. Good luck!

—description from the publisher

Using two standard decks of playing cards the players move marbles (the dogs) around a player board trying to be the first to return their dogs home from their kennels.  It is played in teams of two with rules for a two player variant with each player playing two colors.

uDog is a beautifully crafted wooden board game that will bring some old-fashioned fun back into your home. In a world that is dominated by screens, this very simple-to-learn, but highly strategic game offers a lot of competition and fun as you gather around the table. Part card game and part board game, this multiplayer challenge is simple to learn and exciting to master.

In Shadow Rivals, you will be leading a team of 8 skillful bandits each with a different specialty, robbing the riches from the extravagant parties that take place every night.
 But there are rival teams that also want to rob these patricians, so you will need all your wits to gain the upper hand, and make sure you get the biggest slice of the pie.
 The church bell has just rung for 6 pm, so put on your cloak and go meet your crew in the dark alley near a fancy mansion. It is now time to roll and show them who leads the most notorious team of bandits in town, laughing all the way to the bank.

Take the role of your favorite animal alchemist as you gather ingredients to craft potions and cast spells to see who is the most powerful!

In Animalchemists, players choose their ingredients in order to craft specific potions using a single action per turn.  If they have what they need, a potion may be crafted, but be aware of what other players are crafting as the ultimate goal is to turn those potions into spells.  The player with the best spells (by point value) at the end of the game wins!

—description from publisher

A dead body was found on a rainy night.
You have to reconstruct the crime to find out the murderer, and prevent further tragedies.

Case #02 is co-operative real-time deduction card game. Players need to exchange alibi cards for more clues. And have to find out the culprit who has no alibi. Players will take points if they successfully determined the culprit before any victims are killed.

This murder-themed game is a game of looking for two true criminals out of nine suspects in a limited time of three minutes. The hint for the perpetrator is limited to the number of the investigators, and not only the time but also the new victims (the people who thought they were suspects are killed by the criminals!) As the reasoning is delayed. It does not matter if you resolve the case beyond three minutes, but the only thing left is the wound.
And the opportunity to point out the killer is only once per game, regardless of the number of players and who is calling it! If this is a single chance, and you can not match the truth, then everyone will be defeated.

Rolling CUBES "Do You Play English?" is a game that allow you to have fun coming up with long sentences with the english words you rolled.

The box contains 13 wooden dice of different colours with words on them. Circled words are worth bonus points when used in a sentence.

You can play 3 different games (as standalone or as a tournament) and a variant based on YAHTZEE (playable solo). The idea of all 4 games is to throw the 13 dice and make the longest sentence possible, also trying to score bonuses (using all 13 dice for example).

Potion 21 combines roguelike elements such as randomly generated dungeons and permadeath with a game everyone already knows: blackjack, making it a great entry-level tabletop game.

Each round consists of constructing a dungeon and getting as far as you can without overdosing on potions (the equivalent of "busting" in blackjack) or being killed by monsters (the equivalent of having a lower score than the dealer).

As the game progresses you get better potions and raise your starting power, but when you die you lose everything and start the whole game over.

The first player to collect 3 immortality potions win the game!

—description from the publisher

Great Cthulhu has trapped your sleeping mind in the Dreamlands. Your dream-self has shattered into multiple fragments, scattered throughout the dream world. It is your task to recover these lost fragments, unravel the story secrets and survive long enough to find the correct key and matching gate to escape and wake up!

Dreamescape is a narrative exploration game driven by story card encounters. Each encounter offers roleplay-like choices that drive the game in divergent directions so the game evolves differently each time you play. Our novel keycode system triggers secret alternative storylines based on collected clues and items! Chance of success is based on your skills, equipment and lore gained so far, while repeated play rewards your experience as you uncover different parts of the story and memory of playing previously guides your choices!

Play one of six unique characters in this solo or 2 player semi co-operative RPG-like survival horror game. Carefully manage your skills and resources, find rare items, gain secret knowledge and wield two uniquely powerful abilities - Deja vu and Lucid dreaming - to stay ahead of the minions of Cthulhu. Explore many hundreds of unique story encounters on your quest to recover the mind fragments and find a Dreamgate to let you wake from the nightmare. Failure will lead to insanity, locked forever in a dream within your own mind!

The game offers multiple interwoven story arcs and plot lines to keep you occupied, with hidden puzzles, traps and lore to uncover but all knowledge comes at a price. The more you experience, the greater your chances of being driven to insanity! To win you must avoid, adapt, or overcome the many dangers of this nightmare world.

—description from the publisher

Armies are marching and the lamps are going out all over Europe. From the trenches of Flanders to steppes of Russia, two colossal military blocs are about to engage in brutal conflict, from which only one can emerge victorious. It is up to you to take control of one of these great alliances. Plot your moves carefully, for within an hour Europe’s fate will be decided.

"An Attrition of Souls" is a light, fast-paced wargame. It uses a unique tile-placement system to simulate the First World War. Each turn, you will randomly draw tiles from a pouch based on your economic points and use them to the best of your ability. The game features a combat system meant to simulate the horrific attrition of this conflict. Strategy is key, as the dice will offer no bloodless victories in this game.

—description from the designer

Throw the die and carefully remove a stick of the colour indicated on the die. The sticks come in several widths. The widest sticks are the hardest to remove, but they count for the most points. Take a deep breath and remember... don’t drop the donut!

Become a Sumo Gnome wrestling to eject your opponent from the tree stump arena!

Use custom dice to move, push, spin and trick your way around the stump, looking for that crucial advantage you'll need to push your opponent off and claim victory!

Sumo Gnomes is a quick and portable game that is ready to play in less than a minute and will pop back in your pocket when battling is done.

—description from the designer

Each player gets 16 Danish cities/towns to visit: 6 cities that all have to visit and 10 random cities/towns. To move around, roll a die and move the rolled number of dots unless you roll a six, in which case you draw a question card. If you answer the question correctly, you get to move a number of dots forward (related to the difficulty of the question).
You win by getting to all your 16 cities/towns first.

—user summary

Seal The Ghosts is an action game using some paper cups with a colored seal.
The goal of the game is to seal as many ghosts as possible and to minimize ghosts in your hand when the game is over."Ghost" is a paper cup, and "Seal" means to put the cup inside of "Ring for Sealing". You can put "Ghost" on the other ghost, but if you want to do it, there must be at least one ghost of the same color under it to be placed on top of it.
The player who sealed all his hand-held ghosts is not the winner, and the one who broke the sealed ghosts is not the loser, but the player who has less ghost in hand at the end of the game is the winner.

—user summary

An incredible new dinosaur graveyard has been discovered, and if the early findings are any indication, it could be a treasure trove of fossils and bones like the world has never seen! In Fossilis, 2 to 5 players become paleontologists working the dig site with shovels, whisk brooms, and chisels looking for a find that could make their career.

Each round, players get two actions to dig at the site or make an extraction. As they remove the top layers of sand, clay, and stone, they'll discover trace fossils, which can be exchanged for tools, the plaster necessary to extract bones, and discovery points. As they delve deeper, precious bones will be exposed. They can make a careful extraction if they have the right amount of plaster, but sometimes shifting the earth to cover up a find and slow down the competition is the right move. Bones on their own can be valuable, but museums are really interested in more complete specimens. Sets of bones can be exchanged for museum cards worth big points!

Fossilis features a unique 3D dig site board, with recessed pockets filled with dinosaur bones, and thick, chunky terrain tiles that cover the dig site. Players have to use strategy, timing, and a little bit of luck if they want to make the best discoveries, get their name in all the paleontology journals, and of course, win the game.

—description from the publisher

Note: The Kickstarter edition supports solo play and includes other game related content. It may be found here Fossilis: Kickstarter Edition.

The Queen requires a new gardener. She will assign a small portion of her royal garden to each candidate to decorate them with her favorite flowers. The gardener who manages to please her majesty with most beautiful flower arrangements, will become Queen's new royal gardener!

Royal Gardeners game is designed for 2 to 5 players, ages 7 and up, with games lasting about 15-25 minutes.

Each player will get one portion of Queen's garden with certain number of spaces. On each of those spaces, players may plant flowers of 6 different colors. Players will also collect cards that represents different goals, each providing certain amount of victory points. At the end of the game, player with most victory points is the winner of the game.

Each turn, a player may choose either to plant flowers or pick a goal card from the middle of the table. When planting flowers, player must choose 2 different colors of any kind, and then, him and all other players, must plant those flowers in their portion of the garden. Flowers must be planted next to each other so it will not be possible to make a perfect arrangement of colors in the garden.

The tactics and the decision that players have to make on their turn is: weather to plant colors they need, in order to fulfill the goal cards, or to skip planting in order to take another goal card that can potentially bring him more victory points at the end of the game.

—description from the designer

User summary
ãƒœãƒ–ã‚¸ãƒ†ãƒ³ãã£ãš (Bob Jiten Kids) is a standalone expansion of Bob Jiten.

Game play is the same as Bob Jiten, except that new character Natasha is introduced. While Natasha is active, question master may not say color words either.

The peaceful school day was interrupted, yet again, with another Super Monster spotted marching toward our city! Of course, only the team of 5 Teenage Morphing Superheroes can stand on its way! They must try to stop the Monster before it reaches the city and unleash the devastation upon its innocent population!

Each round a card with the monster attack will be revealed. Players will secretly play cards in order to try to defend from Monster attacks. Players are not allowed to say what cards they are playing. When all cards are revealed, collectively they must beat the correct type of attack that the monster is threatening with.

Instead of fighting, players may play "selfie" cards. That way, a player is slacking in combat but will earn him a victory point. At the end of the game, the player with greatest popularity on social networks is the winner of the game, or, if Super Monster reaches the city, all players lose.

This is a semi-coop game, where players must balance between fighting monster (for greater good) or be selfish and collect victory points, and try to persuade others that "they really need to beat the monster this time".

Hannibal ad Portas is the first title of the One Page Games series: it’s a quick historical game where you play the role of Hannibal on his march from Spain to Italy, where he will meet the Roman Army at Cannae (216BC).

One Page Games (1PG) have been designed with the objective of being “light” games in terms of:

     Time 
     Table space
     Cost


I’ve found it more and more difficult to find the time to study a full-featured game while often I’ve got a 30 minutes break in the daily routine: 1PG have been designed to fill this small interval. Rules are easy and short enough to provide a quick but interesting gaming session: from this perspective 1PG are great for a flight since they perfectly fit on the small space of a plane seat.

Each 1PG must follow two design rules:

     All the components for the game can be placed on a single A4 sheet of paper (no counter, no dice).
     The same deck of 18 cards is used by all the games to provide randomness without the need of using dice.


In addition, you will only need a pencil and a rubber.

—description from the designer

LET THE VIKING AGE BEGIN! The continent of Europe has faced many battles in the past, but none as brutal as what is about to become a 250-year conquest. Ragnar Lothbrok, disenchanted with his chieftain's progress, decides to cross the oceans by boat and discover new, richer civilisations. Now it's your turn to engage in combat and seek to conquer this new world alongside him. Play as one of five fully customised Viking tribes, including uniquely influential Viking longship game pieces, as you try to invade and capture the nine regions of Europe. With special Cards of the Gods to help boost your forces or ruin your plans, and special Raid cards to capture strategic strongholds and gain new warriors, this edition of Risk is an epic battle for control of Europe... and its vast riches. See you in Valhalla!

—from publisher's website

“Nana Korobi Ya Oki” - Falling seven times, getting up eight…
Kami is a game of successive confrontations, which will choose the winner after several rounds.
To win a round, you just have to put your eighth and last card in play, which indicates the number of winning points won. 
The first player or team to reach 15 points wins the game.

—description from the publisher

KAMI is a Goita based game, a traditional 4 players japanese game, but with new rules for 2 or 3 players

Troubled times blight England since the good and just King Richard the Lionheart was captured in the Crusades. Meanwhile, Robin of Locksley is stealing from the rich Norman lords to free the King.

In Robin of Locksley, you aim to collect loot tiles with your Robin and sell loot collections of the same color. Move forward on the racing track surrounding the 5x5 loot tiles by spending earned gold. Every field will give you a task to gather fame: You may fulfill the task, or you may spend one gold coin to pass it. Whoever first circles the racing track twice wins.

—description from the publisher
